data.title: Cboe boosts sales growth guide after Q3 beat; starts portfolio realignment
data.description:
Cboe Global Markets (CBOE) on Friday raised its full-year guidance for organic net revenue growth, while lowering its expense outlook, after posting a double-beat on third-quarter headline results. Shares gained 4.6% minutes after the opening bell.

Meanwhile, the derivatives exchange said it's realigning its business portfolio in order to focus on core strengths and emerging growth opportunities. This includes starting a sales process for Cboe Australia and Cboe Canada; discontinuing U.S. and European corporate listings efforts; and lowering costs tied to the U.S. and European exchange-traded product listings businesses, Cboe Europe Derivatives and several of Cboe's smaller risk and market analytics units.

"Our Australian and Canadian equities businesses have consistently performed well and earned a reputation for innovation, reliability, and customer service. We believe these businesses are well positioned for future growth under new ownership," said Chris Isaacson, executive vice president, chief operating officer at Cboe Global Markets.

The company now expects FY2025 organic total net revenue to rise in the "low double-digit to mid-teens," a boost from the previous "high single-digit" target. Also for the year, Cboe Data Vantage organic net revenue growth is expected to be "high single-digit to low double-digit," vs. "mid to high single-digit" in the prior goal.

It also sees 2025 adjusted operating expense of $827M-$842M (midpoint $834.5M), down from $832M-$847M ($839.5M) in the earlier objective.

Q3 adjusted EPS of $2.67, topping the $2.53 average analyst estimate, climbed from $2.46 in Q2 and $2.22 a year before.

Q3 net revenue of $605.5M, vs. $592.4M consensus, drifted up from $587.3M in the prior quarter and $532.0M in Q3 2024.

Cash and spot markets revenue was $415.0M, down from $487.6M in Q2 and $434.1M in last year's Q3.

Data Vantage revenue rose to $162.1M from $158.3M in Q2 and $145.6M in Q3 2024.

Derivatives markets revenue of $564.6M compared with $527.6M in Q2 and $476.0M in Q3 2024. The 15% Y/Y increase was "propelled by multiple quarterly volume records set across the options business," noted Executive Vice President and CFO Jill Griebenow.

Total adjusted operating expenses were $210.2M, down from $213.3M in Q2 and up from $204.0M in Q3 2024.

data.title: Amazon’s earnings rally shines spotlight on the ETF market
data.description:
Amazon (AMZN) shares surged 11.5% on Friday after the e-commerce giant delivered quarterly results that topped Wall Street expectations.

The company beat estimates across net sales, profit, and subscription revenue, while its Amazon Web Services unit posted a robust 20% year-over-year gain. 

The upbeat report fueled optimism across the tech sector, lifting the Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) and boosting sentiment in numerous exchange traded funds heavily exposed to Amazon. 

The Seattle-based company is currently held in 617 ETFs, which collectively own more than 1.3 billion shares.

Outlined below are Wall Street’s 10 ETFs that have the largest allocation towards AMZN.

No. 1: Global X PureCap MSCI Consumer Discretionary ETF (GXPD), 34.77% allocation. 

No. 2: ProShares Online Retail ETF (ONLN), 24.46% allocation. 

No. 3: Fidelity MSCI Consumer Discretionary Index ETF (FDIS), 22.64% allocation. 

No. 4: Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLY), 22.35% allocation. 

No. 5: Vanguard Consumer Discretionary ETF (VCR), 21.54% allocation. 

No. 6: VanEck Consumer Discretionary TruSector ETF (TRUD), 21.15% allocation. 

No. 7: Direxion Daily Consumer Discretionary Bull 3x Shares (WANT), 20.99% allocation. 

No. 8: ProShares Long Online/Short Stores ETF (CLIX), 20.33% allocation.

No. 9: VanEck Retail ETF (RTH), 20.20% allocation. 

No. 10: Roundhill AMZN WeeklyPay ETF (AMZW), 19.92% allocation. 

Amazon Performance and Ratings

  • 1-Month: +2.1%.
  • 6-Month: +20.8%.
  • Year-to-date: +1.5%.
  • SA Quant Rating: 3.48.
  • SA Analyst Rating: 3.94.
  • Wall Street Rating: 4.71.

data.title: WeRide granted license to operate driverless robotaxis in UAE
data.description:
• WeRide (WRD) has been granted a federal level license by the United Arab Emirates' Regulations Lab to operate fully driverless robotaxis.
  • The UAE’s Regulations Lab is a government initiative that develops and tests emerging and technologies to be deployed across the Emirates.
  • The federal level license allows WeRide’s (WRD) robotaxis to operate in the UAE commercially without an onboard safety driver.
  • China’s WeRide (WRD) had already been operating robotaxis in the Abu Dhabi since December 2024, including the May launch of driverless vehicles through a partnership with Uber (UBER).
  • There are currently more than 100 WeRide (WRD) robotaxis in the Middle East.
  • Shares opened more than 3% lower, reversing a premarket gain of 4%.
  • Source: SEC filing

data.title: MEG Energy meeting on Cenovus deal postponed another week
data.description:
MEG Energy (OTCPK:MEGEF) said Friday its special shareholders meeting to vote on Cenovus Energy's (CVE) takeover proposal has been rescheduled to November 6 to allow time to disclose more information on asset sales.

MEG (OTCPK:MEGEF) Chairman James McFarland adjourned an investor meeting Thursday in Calgary after hours of delay, deferring a vote that had been scheduled for 9 a.m. Calgary time because of a "regulatory inquiry" that the company did not explain; it was the third time MEG has set a new date for the meeting.

Earlier this week, Cenovus (CVE) increased its takeover offer C$30/share in cash or 1.255 Cenovus shares for each MEG (OTCPK:MEGEF) share in order to secure the support of Strathcona Resources (OTCPK:STHRF), MEG's biggest shareholder; as part of the announcement, Cenovus said it was selling some assets in Saskatchewan and Alberta to Strathcona for C$150 million.

Strathcona (OTCPK:STHRF) kicked off the bidding war in May with an unsolicited bid that was opposed by the MEG (OTCPK:MEGEF) board.

data.title: AutoNation announces additional up to $1B share repurchase authorization
data.description:
AutoNation (AN) said on Friday that the automotive retailer's board has authorized an additional up to $1B stock buyback program.

Year-to-date through October 30, the company has repurchased 3M shares for an aggregate purchase price of $576M, or $189 per share.

The company said it now has ~$1.28B authorization remaining for share repurchases.

AutoNation had ~36M shares outstanding as of October 30, and has reduced its shares outstanding by 8% since December 31, 2024.

data.title: Battery Mineral Resources appoints new CFO
data.description:
• Battery Mineral Resources (BMR:CA) (BTRMF) appoints Jennifer Fulton Anderson as chief financial officer.
  • Current CFO Max Satel to depart the company effective October 31, 2025.
  • Fulton Anderson previously worked in equity research and investment banking at Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs.

data.title: Dallas Fed's Logan would have preferred no rate change
data.description:
Dallas Fed President Lori Logan said on Friday the U.S. economic outlook didn't call for cutting rates, as inflation "appears likely to exceed the FOMC’s 2% target for too much longer."

"The labor market remains balanced and cooling slowly. Inflation remains too high, taxing the budgets of businesses and families," she will say, according to prepared remarks at a Dallas Fed conference on The Evolving Landscape of Bank Funding. Logan isn't a voting member of the Federal Reserve's policymaking arm this  year.

Logan's view highlights the shifting and diverging views of the Federal Open Market Committee's members. Most of the voting members agreed to cut the federal funds rate target range by 25 basis points on Wednesday, but Kansas City Fed President Jeffrey Schmid voted to keep the rate unchanged, while Federal Reserve Governor Stephen Miran sought to cut the rate by 50 bps.

Furthermore, she said she'd find it "difficult to cut rates again in December unless there is clear evidence that inflation will fall faster than expected or that the labor market will cool more rapidly."

The Federal Open Market Committee has already mitigated downside risks to the labor market by cutting rates at the September meeting, she noted. "The remaining risks to employment are ones we can monitor closely and respond to if they are becoming more likely to materialize, not ones that currently warrant further preemptive action," she said.

Developing... check back for updates.
